channel.title: yudel tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from yudel.

item.description:
@Green_Footballs When one party is pro-virus for whatever nefarious reasons, and the other party tries to remain above politics by not engaging with the other side’s bad-faith arguments, this is what you get.
@Green_Footballs It also helps that Ivy League media people can’t imagine that evil super predators could look like Ivy League media people.

A reminder that the NYTimes and the Atlantic are fundamentally as parochial in terms of targeting a certain ethnic and demographic community as is your local Jewish weekly newspaper. https://t.co/OMtKB87f2T
Good thread on the incentives that lead to the publication of op-Ed by people who claim to have been “silenced” rather than the people who actually are. https://t.co/fQHDIFPKJa
Your reminder that Republicans no longer believe in local government if the locals will vote for Democrats. True in Texas and Pennsylvania. https://t.co/TmJLZPRzPE
@DeadsoundApp Looks like it shall be released on November 8. https://t.co/ypxEdu7Ely
@DeadsoundApp It’s a new morning for @scottwarmuth1.

If you've been holding off on shopping at https://t.co/rU2kqgQxF4 until you could get a 15% discount to celebrate a hashtag worthy international holiday which honor gender equity in a manner far easier than actually, you know, implementing gender equity, well, now is your chance! https://t.co/Cb7QHeeXy9
@rmneiss I'm guessing this is one of the definitive codices? Aleppo or Leningrad?
Your reminder that not all superheroes wear capes... because capes raise complicated halachic problems regarding tzitzit. https://t.co/HK7zaIZjf6

Relevant line from this Friday's @JewishStandard D'var Torah by Rabbi Lindsey Healey-Pollack: "By attacking the rear, Amalek specifically targeted those who were weakest -- children, the elderly, and the ill. " https://t.co/f2SWBnzTPI
@DBashIdeas I came to YU eager to find “synthesis.” ….

Your occasional reminder that the Republican extremists have spent decades encouraging climate-destroying gasoline consumption on behalf of their fossil fuel oligarch paymasters. https://t.co/oMMBMATivX
@kampeas It’s all fun and games until your cat bites — and breaks — your laptop’s touchscreen.
Funny how this happens. https://t.co/MEuo15eGAb
@AryehCW Not quite true: https://t.co/OZvHkMbPUn
Some good news for those of us who work late on Tuesday nights. https://t.co/6ecWY8WLwP
Republican Party’s antisemitism problem continues. https://t.co/cKB8n2H4Is
@yitzlandes It never hurts to be good looking when you’re placing your op ed.
@shirahanau @JTAnews Your byline will be missed!
@AkivaMCohen Could he be laying the groundwork for an insanity defense regarding the underlying crimes?
@catfitz @Iron_Man_Actual The new pomodoro method.

1/ A question for any datacrunchers among my followers. I have a CSV file with roughly 1000 rows and 100 column. Each row is one response to a hundred questions open ended survey. What is your favorite kosher restaurant? What is your favorite Jewish organization? Etc.
2/ For each column, I’d like to generate a sorted table of the most popular non-NULL answers, along with how many responses that answer got.
3/ I would like to separately see a list of all unique entries, so I can massage the data to eliminate misspellings and the like so all entries reading “TA Pizza” in column five can be changed to “Tel Aviv Pizza.”
4/ I am rather platform agnostic; I have MS and Libre Office, with their spreadsheets and databases; I’m willing to install a desktop SQL and run Python code; and I’m happy to use a cloud service like Airtable or Tableaux.
5/ I could code a solution in Perl, but I imagine there are easier solutions out there. So what do you suggest?
Your occasional reminder not to let your sister read your journal where you plan your violent response to demographic change. https://t.co/7UCVqVWiOE
@jeremyfprice @ElishevaAvital I have no idea. But a publisher would rather publish one textbook than a separate Texas edition.
